member.summary: Word/phrase prefix. Wildcard is appended to term/pattern.

member.name: T:FistCore.Core.ContainsPredicate
member.summary: Performs full-text search by using specialized text indexes.

remarks.para: ContainsPredicate cannot be created by using its constructor. Use to create predicates.
Represents a predicate used to search columns containing character-based data types for precise or fuzzy (less precise) matches to single words and phrases.

CONTAINS can search for:
One or more specific words and/or phrases (simple term). A word is one or more characters without spaces or punctuation. A valid phrase can consist of multiple words with spaces with or without punctuation between them. For example, croissant is a word, and caf au lait is a phrase. Words and phrases such as these are called simple terms.
A word or a phrase where the words begin with specified text (prefix term). In case of a phrase, each word within the phrase is considered to be a prefix. For example, the term auto tran* matches automatic transmission and automobile transducer.

CONTAINS expression is automatically rendered as a compatibile LIKE predicate if it is disabled in the application's *.config file or if the target is not supported. Currently, SQL Server and Oracle DBMSs are supported. The full-text search can be disabled by adding the following setting in the appSettings section of the application's *.config file: <add key="FistCore.Core.ContainsPredicate.Enabled" value="false"/>

CONTAINS predicate cannot be used arbitrarily. Requirements:
Specialized indexing service, such as Microsoft Full-text Search or Oracle Text.
Full-text index must be created/enabled for the target column.

member.name: T:FistCore.Core.SearchCondition
member.summary: A search condition specifies the characteristics of rows to be affected by a query or rule. It consists of one or more boolean conditions (predicates) which evaluate to TRUE, FALSE, or UNKNOWN.

remarks.para: Specifies the conditions for the rows returned in the result set for a SELECT statement, query expression, or subquery. For an UPDATE statement, specifies the rows to be updated. For a DELETE statement, specifies the rows to be deleted.
Search condition is a combination of one or more predicates linked by the logical operators "AND" and "OR".

member.name: F:FistCore.Core.SearchCondition.predicateExpression
member.summary: Contains a combination of predicates, condition operators and sub conditions. A condition operator (AND/OR) is placed between to predicates/sub conditions. All elements of the list implement IRenderSql interface. Only PredicateBase or ConditionOpearator objects are in the list.

member.name: T:FistCore.Core.GroupByClause
member.summary: Specifies the groups into which output rows of a are to be placed.

remarks.para: The GROUP BY clause is used to produce aggregate values for each row in the result set. The GROUP BY clause restricts the rows of the result set; there is only one row for each distinct value in the grouping column or columns. Each result set row contains summary data related to the specific value in its grouping columns.
Restrictions. Some RDBMSs don't support GROUP BY clause for all field types. Eg. the text, ntext, or image data type cannot be used in a GROUP BY clause on SQL Server 7 and 2000.

member.name: M:FistCore.Core.GroupByClause.#ctor

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the GroupByClause class.
member.param: Grouping columns.

member.name: M:FistCore.Core.GroupByClause.#ctor(FistCore.Core.SelectItemCollection)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the GroupByClause class.
member.param: Select list from which the grouping columns are extracted.
member.remarks: Very often a GROUP BY clause contains all the columns in the select list. This method adds all columns found in the given select list to the GROUP BY clause. Other select list items such as aggregate functions are skipped.

member.name: T:FistCore.Core.OrderByClause
member.summary: Specifies the sort for the result set of a .

remarks.para: Contains a list of order by expressions. An order by expressions specifies a column on which to sort and the sort direction. Ascending (ASC) direction sorts from the lowest value to highest value. Descending direction (DESC) sorts from the highest value to lowest value. Null values are treated as the lowest possible values.
OrderByClause may be also used to create a sort expression for a (see ).
Restrictions. Some RDBMSs don't support ORDER BY for all field types. Eg. the text, ntext, or image data type cannot be used in an ORDER BY clause on SQL Server 7 and 2000.

member.name: M:FistCore.Core.SelectStatement.FillCollection(System.Collections.IList,FistCore.Core.IObjectFiller,System.Int32)
member.summary: Executes a query and directly fills given collection with objects build from retrieved data.
member.param: A collection to fill with objects built from data.
Builds objects directly from retrieved data.
Sets timeout for collection fetching SQL command. Default is 30 seconds.

remarks.para: The method uses provided converter to directly build specified object type from data contained in objects, thus skipping the need to create intermediate data structures such as and objects. This can increase performance and reduce memory consumption when working with very large results sets.

member.name: P:FistCore.Core.SelectStatement.Alias
member.summary: Gets or sets query alias. Has no effect on actual select statement but some other statements use it. Eg. if a sub-query is used as a select item in the select list than it should have an alias.

member.name: P:FistCore.Core.SelectStatement.Distinct
member.summary: Gets or sets the value which specifies that only unique rows can appear in the result set.

remarks.para: Performance. Be careful when using DISTINCT if retrieving a lot of large data as the database performance may be considerably degraded.
Restrictions. Some RDBMSs don't support DISTINCT for all field types. Eg. the text, ntext, or image data type cannot be selected as DISTINCT on SQL Server 7 and 2000.

NULL values. For the DISTINCT keyword, null values are considered to be duplicates of each other. When DISTINCT is included in a SELECT statement, only one NULL is returned in the results, regardless of how many null values are encountered.

member.name: P:FistCore.Core.SelectStatement.Top
member.summary: Gets or sets the value that specifies the maximum number of rows that are retrieved. Has no effect if it is set to zero or a negative value; or if the target DBMS doesn't support it.

member.name: T:FistCore.Core.Settings
member.summary: Contains framework settings whose value can be configuraed in appSettings section of the application's configuration file.

member.name: F:FistCore.Core.Settings.ContainsPredicateEnabled
member.summary: Defiens whether is enabled or whether compatibile LIKE expressions are generated.
member.value: true to enable full text search if implemented for target DBMS. false to disable full text search for all DBMSs. Default is true.
member.remarks: The feature can be switched on or off in appSettings section of the application's configuration file. The folowing example shows how to disable the feature: <add key="FistCore.Core.ContainsPredicate.Enabled" value="false"/>

member.name: F:FistCore.Core.Settings.ParentsFetchedInSingleSelect
member.summary: Defines whether and classes fetch all parents in a large single SELECT statement with multiple JOINs.
member.value: true to use single SELECT for all parents; false otherwise. Default is false.

remarks.para: When set to false FistCore will execute multiple, ie. one per parent, atomic SELECTs with parent's PK in WHERE clase. When set to true FistCore executes one large SELECT with child's PK in WHERE clause. This reduces the number of round trips to database, but in sam cases performance may be worse.

The feature can be switched on or off in appSettings section of the application's configuration file. The folowing example shows how to enable the feature: <add key="FistCore.Core.EntityDAO.ParentsFetchedInSingleSelect" value="true"/>

member.name: F:FistCore.Core.Settings.GenericHierarchicalQueryExecutorMaxLevel
member.summary: Defines maximum tree depth for .
member.value: Maximum level. Default is 100.
member.remarks: The value can configured in appSettings section of the application's configuration file. <add key="FistCore.Core.GenericHierarchicalQueryExecutor.MaxLevel" value="100"/>
